sub_title: Maastricht University, Faculty of Health, Medicine and Life Sciences Policy officer/ project manager School for Mental Health and Neuroscience (MHeNs) / Coordinator European Graduate School of Neuroscience (EURON)
summary:
* Policy officer / project manager School for Mental Health and Neuroscience (MHeNs), Faculty of Health, Medicine and Life (FHML) Sciences; 
* Programme coordinator European Graduate School for Neuroscience (EURON).
Working closely together with the Director of MHeNs and EURON on strategic educational and research collaborations with international and national partner universities.

Expertise and roles: coordinating, organizing and helping to shape the establishment, implementation and further development of doctoral (PhD) programmes (content based and transferable skills training elements); establishing joint doctorates between partner universities; project coordination and management of European and national grants (and submission of applications). Roles in approved projects (support project management, internal and external communication with partners of the consortium and stakeholders such as industrial partners and patiënt representaties, organizing events and training);  preparation of  information and policy materials on behalf of the organisations. 

Competencies: teamwork, building relationships (networking), interpersonal skills, responsibility, research and investigating, results oriented, autonomy, organisational sensitivity, planning and organising, personal motivation.

My background, being trained as a (cell) biologist with a PhD (1995) in the oncology field and as postdoc (1995-1999) in the immunology field, provides me the biomedical background to function as programme coordinator and project manager of MHeNs and EURON to initiate and develop new joint training and research programmes and to stimulate mobility and exchange possibilities for master and PhD students for the promotion of cooperation between universities.

projects.title: Youth-GEMs - EU HORIZON-HLTH-2021-STAYHLTH-01 Programme
projects.description:
To investigate the role of genetic and environmental factors in mental health of young people.
The aims are: to advance the molecular and neurobiological understanding of the interplay between genetic, epigenetic, and environmental factors in driving or preventing the transition from mental health to mental illness in young people; to provide youth and health professionals evidence-based tools and instruments for robust assessment of mental ill-health and for prediction of mental health trajectories.
Coordinator: Psychiatry and Neuropsychology, Maastricht University, NL - Prof. B. Rutten / Assoc. Prof. S. Gülöksüz
Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland, Dublin - Prof. M. Cannon

projects.title: NEURIPIDES -  EU Joint Programme Neurodegenerative Disease Research (JPND) 2020
projects.description:
Neurofeedback for self-stimulation of the brain as therapy for Parkinson Disease
Coordinator:
School for Mental Health and Neuroscience, Maastricht University, Maastricht, The Netherlands
Partners:
Clinic for Stereotaxy and Functional Neurosurgery, Universität zu Köln/ University Hospital of Cologne, Cologne, Germany
Department of Neurology, Charles University, Prague, Czech Republic
Neurospin-INSERM  and Medical school of Université de Versailles, Paris-Saclay, Paris, France
Department of Neurology, Toronto University / Toronto Western Hospital, University Health Network, Ontario, Canada
Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, National Magnetic Resonance Research Center (UMRAM), Bilkent University, Bilkent, Ankara, Turkey
Brain Innovation B.V. , Maastricht, The Netherlands

Our aim is to develop a new treatment modality for Parkinson’s disease (PD), based on self-regulation of brain circuits with neurofeedback. We will capitalize on the advancement in the understanding of pathophysiological networks of PD and neural mechanisms of treatments accumulated during 25 years of DBS and neuroimaging research in order to develop a new approach to network modulation, non-invasively through neurofeedback.

projects.title: STREAMLINE - EU HORIZON-WIDERA-2021-ACCESS-02 (Twinning Western Balkans) Programme
projects.description:
Strengthening regional stem cells based research for advancement of multi modal innovative strategy for modelling neurodevelopmental disorders.
Coordinator: INSTITUT ZA MOLEKULARNU GENETIKU I GENETICKO INZENJERSTVO, Belgrado, Serbia - Prof. Milena Stevanovic 
Partners: 
CARDIFF UNIVERSITY, School of Biosciences, United Kingdom – Prof. Adrian Harwood
UNIVERSITEIT MAASTRICHT, MHeNs, Netherlands – Prof. David Linden
ETHNIKO KENTRO EREVNAS KAI TECHNOLOGIKIS ANAPTYXIS ( \CENTRE FOR RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY HELLAS CERTH), Institute of Applied Biosciences, Greece – Prof. Spyros Petrakis

Neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs) caused by alterations in early brain development are a group of complex and heterogeneous disorders that give rise to the psychiatric conditions such as autism spectrum disorders, intellectual disability, schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. The goals of STREAMLINE are to enhanced strategic networking and reinforce research and innovation potential of the Institute of Molecular Genetics and Genetic Engineering (IMGGE) in order to develop IMGGE as a high capacity hub for research of NDDs in the Western Balkans which is able to integrate with similar centres in Europe. The project objectives are: a) to enhance the current and scale up the overall strategic networking activities between the IMGGE and internationally-leading European partners and regional partners; b) to raise the research profile of research stuff and scientific attractiveness of IMGGE in the field of NDDs; c) to strengthens research management capacities and administrative skills of the IMGGE staff and d) to become a regional leader in innovations tackling NDDs. Objectives will be achieved through networking, staff exchanges, training, summer schools, symposia, workshops, participation at conferences and dissemination in scientific community, industries and public.

projects.title: NENS cluster call grant for Education and Training "Advanced Skill training in Neuroscience courses: a case study of Drugs and the Brain" - Training element of the PhD programme  EURON - Workshops Drugs and the Brain (start date: 2001 - 2023)
projects.description:
Call Dec. 2020 - Organization and development: Jan. 2021 - Sept. 2021
Online course: 27-30 September 2021

 

The course “Advanced Skill Training in Neuroscience Courses: a Case Study of Drugs & Brain” has been awarded, by the FENS Committee for Higher Education and Training (FENS-CHET), with the grant for the “Education and Training Clusters” call,  aiming to stimulate and strengthen the cooperation among NENS schools. This grant is supported by the FENS  and IBRO-PERC.

 
Organizers:
European Graduate School of Neuroscience (EURON)
University of Crete, Faculty of Medicine, Heraklion, Crete, Greece
University College Cork, Cork, Ireland
University of Minho, School of Medicine, Braga, Portugal

This multidisciplinary four-day course covers all major neurobiological aspects related to traditional psychopharmacological treatments and new developments in drug modulation of brain function (including classical neuropsychopharmacological agents, cognitive enhancers, illicit drugs and nutraceuticals), its underlying mechanisms, as well as targetable biological systems and processes (microbiome & gut-brain axis, the blood-brain barrier and neuroinflammation). The four days cover topics related to: Psychiatry, Reward, Psychedelics and Aging and Cognition.

The set-up of the course is intended to encourage active participation of students and to stimulate interaction between experts and participants. After expert lectures in the morning, students will work on challenging problems or statements, present and discuss the outcome in a plenary meeting, during live-streamed Q&A sessions. Role: programme coordinator,

projects.title: Joint Programme Neurodegenerative Diseases "Targeting dysregulation in the brainstem in Alzheimer's Disease" (EPI-AD)
projects.description: The main aim of the project was to establish the exact role of DNA (hydroxy)methylation within the brainstem in the development and course of AD. By integrating classical and pioneering hypotheses on the aetiology of AD, this translational, multi-level approach will identify novel (epigenetic-based) loci and pathways to be used in order to better diagnose, prevent, attenuate or possibly reverse AD’s pathophysiology. In EPI-AD, academic partners collaborate intensively to offer a well-defined and balanced research and training programme to young researchers. The benefits for the participating young researchers are: 1) exposure to different academic partners which will create a balanced and sustainable network for the rest of their career; 2) participation in different workshops and meetings will broaden their scope of different knowledge resources; 3) access to state-of-the-art knowledge and expertise from leading scientists with academic, clinical and industrial backgrounds; 4) an international multi-disciplinary training environment which is an optimal preparation for an international (European) research career; 5) high quality guidance which will leads to the optimal use of talents of researchers; 6) a strong sense of European citizenship which encourages researchers to work in an international (European) context; 7) the research environment offering the latest technologies and methodologies. Role: WP co-leader Training.

projects.title: EU Tempus and Bilateral Cooperation with Industrialised Countries: JOINT DEGREE Project _ Edu-Neuro EU-JP: Double European-Japan Master Degree in Neuroscience
projects.description: The consortium consists of 4 European (Maastricht University, Universite catholique de Louvain, University of Lille 1, University of Cologne) and 3 Japanese universities (University of Toho, Tohoku and Kyoto Prefectural University of Medicine) that each offer accredited Master programmes in Biomedicine. he goals of the project is to implement a Double European - Japan Master's Degree program in Biomedicine with a specialization in Neuroscience. Role: programme coordinator and project manager.

projects.title: European Master in Neuroscience (EMiN) - Erasmus Lifelong Learning Programme - Curriculum Development
projects.description: Eight universities and a university hospital in three countries within a range of 150 km want to meet the challenges in the field of neuroscience by the realization of a European Master in Neuroscience (EMiN). EMiN offers thorough knowledge of and extensive experience with the theories and skills in the domain of normal function of the nervous system. EMiN wants to exploit wider competences and resources by recruiting excellent students who will be given the opportunity to learn techniques in biotechnology, biomedicine and imaging that could be valued to employment in clinical settings and industry. EMiN guarantees an outstanding international research training program in Translational Neuroscience. Specific expertise in various disciplines related to Neuroscience will offer the educational and research expertise for interdisciplinary training of the students. The partners will supply laboratory space and infrastructure and the opportunity to get access to foreign expertise within a joint framework. The Master degree will be organized as a joint degree program and therefore contributes to the Bologna principles.  The active collaboration with industrial enterprises leads to exchange of high-tech knowledge and expertise between academic and industrial partners. The Dutch government supports this project as it contributes to cross border educational cooperation. Role: project manager.

projects.title: European Graduate School of Neuroscience - EU FP6 - Marie Curie Actions "Structuring the ERA"
projects.description:
The project (“EURON”) aims to develop and strengthen EURON as a high profile, multidisciplinary research training site. The main objective of EURON is to train a critical mass of young early stage researchers in basic, cognitive and clinical neuroscience in a European and interdisciplinary perspective by pooling the resources of 8 European universities and research institutes, and 3 industrial organisations. This site will be open to PhD students within the EURON-participating universities and PhD students from outside EURON. In the context of international mobility, EURON will offer to early stage researchers a coherent training program providing the possibility to perform integrated research on function and dysfunction of the CNS and behaviour with a particular focus on bridging the gap between fundamental neuroscience and applied clinical, cognitive, and behavioral neuroscience, via:
•	an integrated and co-ordinated training programme 
•	an international EURON PhD degree/certificate on top of the PhD degree awarded by their home university, and
•	the possibility to gain insight into research and development processes at pharmaceutical companies and biotechnology SMEs.
The training programme of EURON will consist of three levels with increasing degrees of advancement. Each phase will comprise individual training and supervision on highly specialized research topics in the laboratories of the partners and an integrated package of courses, seminars, Winter Schools and Fellows Days. Role: programme coordinator and project manager.

projects.title: EURON Doctoral Training Programme in basic Neuroscience - EU FP5 Marie Curie Training Site
projects.description:
EURON provides a training programme for post-graduate students that aims at: education of students in a multidisciplinary way in basic, clinical and behavioural neurosciences via theoretical and practical training through courses, workshops, individual guidance and the possiblity for the so-called continuous education within the rapidly expanding field of neuroscience. The students will be trained via integrative courses in various specialisations and thus enables them to become fully multidisciplinary oriented in the
future.  A major feature of EURON is its international character, which is reflected in the research and educational  program, and its organisation. This will provide the ideal environment for training the PhD students to function smoothly in international institutions within the European Union.
